campaign.story:
**After the KickStarter campaign has ended, you can pre-order or purchase your McRoboFace here**
Video Credits: Francesco Vannini (@GarageTechTweet)
McRoboFace - Add Character to your Creations!
We all like adding blinky LEDs to our electronics creations, whether it is a robot, weather station or something that reads and displays sensor data. Now with McRoboFace you can add emotions to everything at the same time as adding blinkies.
All the 17 RGB LEDs are fully addressable and can be controlled by most processors in the field using standard "neopixel" code. This includes Raspberry Pi, Crumble, Arduino, ESP8266, micro:bit and Codebug.
CrumbleBot with McRoboFace
  Pictures of Prototypes in the Wild
Tim Morley
Tim and his 10 year old son are making a great robot project using a Raspberry Pi, Picon Zero and McRoboFace.

  Robin Newman has designed a circuit to extract the volume from an audio signal so that his McRoboFace can sing along to Bach! Also, the clip below shows 2 McRoboFaces talking to each other, using SonicPi. How cool is that?
You can now select a pledge reward that includes the components shown in the video for the Singalong project:
400 point Breadboard
Capacitors and resistors
Breadboard friendly trimming potentiometer
3.5mm stereo jack lead
Male-Female Jumper leads
Pushbutton with cap
Note that the Picon Zero is NOT included in the kit. Other ADC boards for the Pi are also available
.
You can use McRoboFace to make programming the BBC micro:bit  even more fun:
PLAY

Why not code your micro:bit and McRoboFace to react to being shaken or tapped? Maybe it should turn blue if it gets cold, or red when hot?
.
What's in a Name?
When the prototype was shown, there were a number of comments that the fun name "McRoboFace" was simply "too silly" :-(
So every backer has one vote to choose the final name for the product. This name will be printed on the back of the PCB and on the packaging. You can choose from
McRoboFace
RoboFace
Each backer, whatever the pledge level, gets one vote. If you want to help select the name, then please pledge! When you have pledged, send a direct email with your vote.
.
Technical Details
McRoboFace has 17 fully addressable LEDs. These will be WS2812B or SK6812 (fully compatible products).
McRoboFace is made on a White PCB with ENIG (gold) plating for reliability
Dimensions: 50 x 40mm
3 mounting holes for M2.5 screws
Mouth comprises 14 LEDs, each 3.5mm square
Nose is a single LED, 3.5mm square
Two LEDs for eyes, both 5mm square
4 Pads to connect: 5V, Ground, Data In and Data Out (for daisy-chaining to another McRoboFace or other "neopixel" strip)
Each McRoboFace will be supplied fully assembled and we will include a 4-way right-angle male header which you can solder on if required. This makes it easy to plug directly into a breadboard.
.
Why Run a Kickstarter Campaign?
Although this is a simple project, we need to have a fully automated process in place to manufacture them to ensure that all pixels are working correctly from the start. To do this, we need to place a minimum order of 1000 units. If you want this product to be available, please support it and pass the message on.
.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is actually a simple project and the prototypes are fully working. The manufacturer has already quoted for various quantities and we can go ahead as soon as funding is confirmed. We will be able to ship within about 4 weeks of placing the order with the manufacturers.

4tronix is a successful business and already has the systems in place for shipping worldwide, so we don't expect any issues there.

The manufacturer will test every pixel on every unit made. The test includes separate Red, Green and Blue as well as a combined White test. There should be no problems with faulty pixels, but we will also do a random test at 4tronix as a double-check before we ship.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
What is the Neutrino?
The Neutrino is an inexpensive, open source, miniaturized version of the Arduino Zero!
Featuring a 32-bit ARM processor running at 48MHz, and boasting 32K of ram, the Neutrino is far more capable than your typical Arduino. And because it has the same processor and pinout, all libraries written for the Zero will work on the Neutrino without any modification!
Finally, being open-source, you're free to modify it as you wish and integrate it into your own designs - without ever needing to pay any royalties or licensing fees!
What's new with version 2.0?
The new version of the Neutrino adds RX/TX pins that were often requested, and is designed to be a bit cheaper to manufacture so that I can continue to offer them at this price point. The USB OTG circuit, which required a costly power multiplexing chip, buffer, and transistor, has been replaced with an inexpensive very low forward voltage diode to isolate the battery from the USB supply. The micro AB connector has also been replaced with a less expensive, but just as sturdy, micro B house part. In addition, the 3.3V LDO regulator, reset button, and status LED have also been changed to house parts. But don't be alarmed; these aren't downgrades. The regulator is a nice modern Texas Instruments part, and the new reset button is slightly larger and has a nicer feel to it!
The Neutrino 2.0!
  Technical Specs
Microcontroller: Atmel ATSAMD21G18 ARM Cortex M0+
Clock speed: 48 MHz
Operating voltage: 3.3V
I/O pin limits: 3.3V, 7 mA
Digital I/O pins: 14, with 12 PWM
Analog input pins: 6, 12-bit ADC channels
Analog output pins: 1, 10-bit DAC
Flash memory: 256 KB
SRAM: 32 KB
Voltage regulator: 3.7-5.5V input / 3.3V, 300mA output
Dimensions: 1.4 x 0.7" (36mm x 18mm)
Neutrino 2.0 PCB Layout
  Programming
Programming is easy! Like most Arduinos, you simply plug the board into your PC using a micro USB cable, select the board you want to program, and hit the upload button in the IDE when you're ready. The Neutrino ships with the Zero bootloader installed, and most of the time it will auto-reset when the USB serial port is opened by the IDE, but in the event that this fails, you can always hit the reset button on the board to force it to enter bootloader mode after your program finishes compiling.
The Neutrino can be programmed with the Arduino IDE via USB, or with the Atmel ICE!
  Programming is easy with the Arduino IDE!
Other Features
Status LED
Like most Arduinos, a green LED is connected to pin 13. This can be used as a status indicator, and on the Neutrino it functions as a power indicator as well; coming on automatically when power is applied to the board.
10-bit DAC
Say goodbye to the Tone() command forever! Turn your Neutrino into a virtuoso by connecting an amplifier to pin A0 an using the Audio library to play .WAV files with the built-in DAC!
LiPo charger compatible
Need to use your Neutrino on the go? The Neutrino features the same pinout on its power pins as Adafruit's Pro Trinket, making it directly compatible with their USB LiPo charging backpack!
Thank you for your support!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Last year after a successful Kickstarter campaign I shipped 500 Neutrinos to backers and this year I shipped over 250 Pixels. A prototype of the Neutrino 2.0 has already been assembled and tested, I've received quotes for manufacture, taken shipping costs and Kickstarter's cut into account, and have chosen components that are available in large quantities from reputable distributors. I don't anticipate any problems delivering the boards on time, and I'll keep you updated every step along the way!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey guys!
Just wanted to let you know that I've launched a new Kickstarter campaign:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/rabidprototypes/tau-the-tiny-32-bit-arduino-zero-compatible

Hey guys!
As some of you may be aware the boards have begun shipping! I got off to a bit of a slow start but lots of them have already shipped, and tons more will be going out next week!
I'm also excited to reveal I've been running myself ragged the last two weeks getting ready for Makerfaire! At the last minute I was invited by Atmel + Microchip to show my boards off in their booth! If you're in the area of New York, you can find me there this Saturday and Sunday from 10am-6pm!

Hey guys,
Just wanted to let you know that Macrofab finished assembling the boards today and they've begun programming and testing them!
I'll be sending out the backer survey shortly. Be sure to fill it out as soon as you get it or your shipment may be delayed!

Hey guys,
I just wanted to let you know that I've just launched a new Kickstarter project!

Hey guys,
Just a quick update to share a photo of the Neutrino PCBs that Macrofab recently received!

Hey guys,
We did it! Thank you so much for backing the project!
The Kickstarter funds won't be transferred to my account for another two weeks, and normally that would mean I couldn't order the boards until then, but since I want to get these back on the market and I have another Kickstarter campaign in the works that I'd like to launch as soon as possible, I decided to put the order in for the boards TODAY!

We're past the halfway point!  Woo hoo!
But at the present rate at which the campaign is being funded it looks like it might make it to only 80%. Oh no!
So, to boost sales I've created several new "Late Riser" rewards!

campaign.story:
The Internet of Things, beacons and The Physical Web are today’s hot topics. Soon we'll be surrounded by small intelligent sensor nodes that analyze the environment and offer people more content on their smartphones.
Many traditional proximity beacon products are already available, but what the market is truly lacking is a capable open-sourced device.
We decided to change this.
A year ago we started a design process with one goal: to create a superior open-source sensor beacon platform to fulfill the needs of developers, makers, hobbyists, students, IoT companies and even normal people.
We managed to create one of the most advanced Bluetooth sensor products in the world.
        What is it?
  RuuviTag is a stand-alone Bluetooth 5 ready sensor beacon platform. It can be used as a standard Eddystone / iBeacon proximity beacon but it has the potential to be so much more.
By having a way to measure: 
Ambient temperature
Relative humidity
Barometric pressure
Altitude
Acceleration
It’s possible to cover several use-cases. And no need to worry about charging the device: the battery has the potential to last up to 10 years depending on the SW used.
RuuviTag is compatible with both Android (4.3.2 or higher) and iOS (8.0 or higher) mobile devices.
   How to Use It?
RuuviTag is an IoT beacon that can be used for almost anything. Sounds cool, huh?
- I want one! But how can I use it? Give me an example.
Fair enough.
We've made it simple. No programming or electronics know-how is required to start with the device.
We've prepared ready-made applications for you to use. And this is just a start. RuuviTag will be a compatible platform with many great open-source projects such as BubblePy, Arduino IDE, Apache Mynewt etc. We also encourage all the backers to join our community.
  Demo 1: A Weather Station
Application on this video is very simple but still extremely useful for everyone. Because the Tag is equipped with state-of-the-art environmental sensors, we decided to make it work as a personal weather station.
In this example the firmware application reads the sensor values, encodes the data using Base91 encoder and broadcasts the address in an Eddystone-URL frame. Nearby mobile phone sees the address and by clicking it, a simple JavaScript on our website decodes the data and shows it in a readable format.
Imagine all the possibilities this simple application enables!
You can put RuuviTags wherever you like to and check the sensor readings from your phone without:
pairing
connecting or 
installing a mobile application.
Android phones (and iOS with Chrome installed) can natively show the nearby beacons.
By running this weather station firmware, the battery of the beacon can potentially last several years.
Go ahead and check it out.
  Demo 2: Configuring the Physical Web
Google's Eddystone is a really powerful open-source beacon format.
This is a simple way to create the Physical Web applications of your own.
Just set the beacon to broadcast a URL address pointing to a website of your choice. From the video, Joe put one in his vintage car making it convenient and handy for the lady looking to rent a car from her mobile phone.
The Eddystone-URL is one of the available frame types Eddystone protocol has. In this demo you can see how the device can be easily configured to broadcast a new URL.
It's also possible to take advantage of other geeky features (UID, TLM and EID) Eddystone has.
Configuration of the parameters is really easy using the GATT service enabled mobile application shown in the video.  
So many ways how to use the Physical Web. Maybe you would like to hide a treasure? We call it spontaneous geocaching.
         The whole idea and technology behind the RuuviTag is bigger than that. Here's why:
   1) The Physical Web
You may have heard of it. The Physical Web is one of Google's projects. ...and a very cool one.
The idea behind the Physical Web is that every object can have their own website. These objects are basically beacons that use Google's Eddystone protocol to broadcast URL addresses everyone can find.
The technology is new and we are one of the first ones taking advantage of it.
  2) Web Bluetooth
This makes things even more interesting. The Web Bluetooth standard allows browsers to communicate with the beacons (two-way communication). This allows our Tag to be something more than just a simple beacon.
And the best part is that it works without needing to install a mobile application.
To fully understand the possibilities this technology enables, this video gives a better (and easier) explanation:
 3) Android Nearby
On this very moment, Google is rolling out a software update for the Android users with a new feature called Nearby. It makes user experience with nearby beacons seamless and is fully compatible with RuuviTags.
Nearby Notifications is a new feature allowing developers to tie an app or website to a BLE beacon and create contextual notifications, even with no app installed.
   What we have created is a powerful open-source beacon platform to help you to take advantage of these new technologies.
  ...and it's affordable!
  Basic model (only nRF52832's internal temperature sensor)
   Advanced model (with all the sensors). BME280 = temperature / humidity / air pressure. LIS2DH12 = 3-axis +-16G accelerometer. FYI: This model has totally three (3) temperature sensors onboard (nRF52 + BME280 + LIS2DH12).
    Let's Support Education!
Don't you think it would be great if students could experiment and learn IoT using cool devices like RuuviTag? We do.
You've got a chance to help by selecting one of the rewards where we promise to ship one RuuviTag+ to a random school. We are helping too by giving out devices for students to use.
An example: A super simple weather station that everyone can access.
Imagine one Tag with a several year battery life broadcasting sensor data outside a school. Students can check their phones for real-time weather information and learn of the possibilities technology enables -- both fun and educational.
And this is just one of the numerous ways the Tag can be used. Older and more advanced young minds could learn by creating similar applications themselves or even create totally new, innovative hardware products.
Open-source simply rocks!
  Easy to Update
RuuviTag is shipped with a preloaded bootloader software. This means it's very straightforward to flash new firmware application Over-the-Air:
We'll be offering various ready-made software for you to use, so:
No programming knowledge of any kind is required to get started with the device.
In addition of the firmware application software, it's also possible to update the bootloader and the Bluetooth protocol stack over-the-air.
This means that once the best Bluetooth chip manufacturer in the world, Nordic Semiconductor, releases its new protocol stack (ie. the Bluetooth 5 support), it can be updated without needing a computer -- super handy and ready for the future of technology.
Updating the firmware over-the-air is supported on both Android and iOS devices.
   Arduino Compatible
When the design progress of the RuuviTag began, we had no idea what kind of platforms would come up in the future. Recently, Arduino has decided to start supporting the same Nordic Semiconductor's nRF52 chip we are using. This is a great thing for Ruuvi users!
RuuviTag is a software compatible platform, which means that makers, hobbyists and students will be able to use the familiar Arduino IDE and its libraries to create their own sensor beacon applications.
   Hardcore Developers
Although it's possible to use the platform by running the ready-made example firmwares on it or create one with help of Arduino, RuuviTag is also a perfect tool for serious development projects.
If using standard Bluetooth stack and bootloader isn't what you're looking for and would like to use the serial wire debug (SWD) bus to hack with your Tag, don't worry.
All the necessary pins and buses (including I2C/SPI/ADC/UART) are available for hardcore evaluation.
We have created a custom Arduino-compatible shield to be used with Nordic Semiconductor's low-cost nRF52-DK evaluation board. Our factory uses similar shields to test the RuuviTags in production.
The perfect tool for badass firmware developers. No need to hassle with wires and batteries.
      Technical Specifications
Nordic Semiconductor nRF52832 SoC
Bosch BME280 environmental sensor (RuuviTag+)
LIS2DH12 3-axis accelerometer (RuuviTag+)
Integrated NFC antenna
CR2450 / CR2477 battery (up to 10 years, depending on the SW used)
-40°C to +85°C (requires a high temperature battery, CR2450HR)
More than 500m (1650 feet) open-air range (depending on the environment and transmission power used)
Normal Lithium coin cell batteries are usually performing ok between -10°C and +70°C (-4F° to 158°F). Please also note that walls etc. will decrease the range.
Because the nRF52 is a future proof system-on-chip software radio, also other protocols apart from Nordic Semiconductor's own Bluetooth stack can be used. There are several option available and RuuviTag is a supported platform for example with Apache Mynewt which is a really cool open-source project:
Apache Mynewt is a community-driven open source OS for embedded and includes the world’s first open source Bluetooth Low Energy stack for constrained devices (MCU)!
  Nordic offers a protocol stack for ANT and RuuviTag is also a Wirepas Connectivity compatible platform:
The Connectivity protocol enables creation of large mesh networks of up to thousands of RuuviTags. They can be connected to the Internet through a single gateway. A great choice for business customers.
The upcoming Bluetooth 5 will also finally bring the Bluetooth mesh communication to reality.
RuuviTag is a Bluetooth 5 ready platform.
   Superior Antenna
Many beacons does have bad antennas and it means shorter battery life.
>500m range doesn't really make sense for most beacon applications, but having a good antenna means that lower transmission power is required thus leading to longer battery life.
In the video (you saw earlier), the chip was transmitting at +4dBm (2.5mW). The next day we made a similar test using -4dBm power (0.4mW). We were overwhelmed by the result: 500 meters (1650 feet). Sweet! Even the chip manufacturer was impressed.
RuuviTag transmitting at -4dBm which is 10 000 times less power compared to the max TX power of the cell phone.
  The max range we've tested is ~1.4 km (~4500 feet)!
 Innovative Battery Holder Mechanism
Using a coin cell battery was a tricky task.
We wanted to create a new way to make a connection to the battery. After much trial and error we came up with a perfect battery holder mechanism.
The circuit board material bends enough to firmly keep the battery in place.
A patent will be pending but we don't like those.
    How did This Project get Started?
There was a demand for an open-source beacon and we decided to make one.
In the beginning this was just a fun project, but we got so many contact requests from companies and developers that we decided to make the project viral and start working with this crowdfunding campaign.
  Design ready for production
We think electronics should look interesting. Especially the devices designed for makers. One of the original goals was to create an innovative beacon that looks like a ring.
   About Ruuvi
Ruuvi began 7 years ago when Lauri was a student at the University of Oulu, Finland.
He launched a website for Finnish electronics hobbyists. Ruuvipenkki (a screw vise in Finnish) became a popular site among embedded electronics hobbyists. This Finland based company, Ruuvi Innovations Ltd (Oy), was founded in 2015 to continue the passion of embedded systems.
RuuviTag is Ruuvi's second project and the first one to be crowdfunded.
Lauri showing RuuviTags at the Maker Party event in Chiang Mai, Thailand
  Ruuvi team ready for The Next Web conference, Amsterdam
  Ruuvi stand at TNW conference
  Presenting RuuviTag in a business meeting
You can find more stories from our blog.
   Manufacturing
Lauri has lived last two years in SE Asia where he met Sharnon Tulabadi, the founder of the U.S. based company Gravitech LLC. Ruuvi decided to run the campaign in cooperation with the Gravitech.
Gravitech has a well known side-branch in Thailand. They have opened a new PCB assembly facility in Bangkok this year. RuuviTag devices will be produced using brand new SMD assembly machinery.
Sharnon with their brand new pick and place machine
The factory is capable of assembling and testing up to 10,000 Ruuvi devices a day and Gravitech is also going to handle the shipment of the devices.
Pick-and-place machine configuration before RuuviTag prototype run.
  Ready, steady, go!
  Inspection and some manual component placing before reflowing in the oven.
    Open-Source FTW!
All the hardware and the software projects of Ruuvi's are open-source.
  Ruuvi Community is contributing to the development of the projects. Everyone is welcome to join the discussion and be a part of the community by requesting an invite to our Slack team.
As the community grows, more example use-cases and demo applications will come up.
You can find more info from our website
  Follow us on Twitter
           Timetable and Usage of the Funds
Multiple prototyping rounds have already been successfully completed and the best component manufacturers and suppliers have been located.
The design is 99% finished has been proven to work. After tuning the antenna it will be even better. In other words, it’s ready to be manufactured.
We've got everything under control.
After the campaign is finished, the funds will be used to purchase the necessary components and circuit boards. A mandatory Bluetooth declaration fee will be also paid using the funds.
In the meanwhile, documentation and example software will be polished.
   What's next?
We've got so many cool ideas about how to make the most out of RuuviTag.
We're excited of what the Physical Web, the Web Bluetooth and the Android Nearby can offer in the future.
Most of the all: we’re excited to hear what kind of use-cases you can come up with the Tags.
There is one more thing we want to share with you even though it's not 100% finished.
In the future RuuviTag will be immortal.
We are prototyping an add-on board called RuuviHarvester. It's a battery replacement board for RuuviTag (and third-party beacons).
RuuviHarvester makes your beacon immortal!
Another exciting project around the corner! ;)
What others say about us on Twitter?
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have already competed several prototype manufacturing rounds without problems, but manufacturing physical devices is always a challenging task. If we encounter any problems that would affect delivery time, we will keep customers updated.

Ruuvi's partner company, Gravitech, has done similar projects and products for many years. We believe that they are our best fit with the knowledge and tools deliver our RuuviTags on time. This campaign is run by Gravitech. They are responsible for the manufacturing and delivering of devices for campaign backers.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
A quick update of what we're doing!
2 months ago we finished shipping the last of the rewards for backers who had answered our shipping survey. Now, after more than one year of hard work, we can finally call this campaign as case closed. But our work has just started. By end of this decade, Ruuvi's goal is to become one of the most well-known open-source IoT hardware innovators in the world.
Soon, we're going to launch a whole new community portal called RuuviLab. It will be full of tutorials and ideas showing how RuuviTags can be used to boost your business or ease your everyday life. We've worked intensively on it for a few months now and we're sure you'll like it. We'll keep you posted when it's live.

We’re delighted to inform you that the shipping of the rewards has been now completed.
If you haven’t received the rewards or email notification telling the shipment is on its way, please let us know by emailing info@ruuvi.com.
FYI, if you’ve answered the shipping address survey not before this week, you might not have received the notification yet.
So, I received the shipment but what can I do with the devices?

Hey!

We’re happy to tell you the shipping of RuuviTags is continuing forward and, currently, our manufacturing and shipping partner, Gravitech, has sent more than half of the rewards.
You’ll receive an email notification after your reward has been shipped.

Merry Christmas!
We’re happy to announce to you that the first rewards are now shipped.
That’s right. We can’t believe it either.
Running the campaign and especially the time put after the campaign has been extremely busy. 90/90 rule that says last 10% of project takes an additional 90% more time is true. Now it feels really relieving to finally tell you the shipping process has begun.

We’re getting closer to completing the production and shipping of our first RuuviTag devices. For the past 2 weeks I’ve been in China pushing things forward. Check this out:
Waterproof custom enclosure
The first stop was at our plastic injection moulding manufacturer in Dongguan, close to Shenzhen.

Hey guys. We have news!
After the previous update, the total amount received from Kickstarter is $152,778.04. Getting the money took longer we expected, but all is good now. Now we would like to tell you exactly what has to be done and how much work is still required before we’re able to start shipping devices.
Component orders

Good news. We're finally going to receive funds from Kickstarter any day now and this means we'll be able to start purchasing components!
RuuviTag Rev.B4
Last night I finished design process of latest RuuviTag revision. It's pretty close to Rev.B3, but a few enhancements are made to ensure reflow process will go as smoothly as possible.

What a ride! We're exhausted, but so happy with the outcome!
You 2,478 backers made this possible. Thank you.

campaign.story:
Mechaduino is an Arduino for mechatronics! Mechaduino is a self-contained motion control platform which allows you to develop your own custom servo mechanisms. It can be also be used as a drop-in servo motor for 3D printers and CNC machines. No more missed steps!
Engineers use servo motors to achieve the precision motion required in applications such as robotics, automation, and CNC manufacturing.  Like RC servos, industrial servos actively correct for external disturbances.  Unlike RC servos, industrial servos can provide very accurate motion, and often support advanced motion control modes.  Unfortunately the cost of industrial servos is prohibitive to the individual maker (thousands of dollars per motor).
We've been developing an affordable open-source industrial servo motor, opening the door to sophisticated mechatronics applications.  Our design leverages the low cost of mass produced stepper motors.  We are able to achieve very high resolution via 14b encoder feedback (after calibration routine!).
  Mechaduino began as a personal project that grew out of our recurring need for affordable, yet capable servo motors. 
We began documenting the project on hackaday.io to share our designs with the world and to get feedback from other makers and engineers.  Encouraged by the overwhelming response, we decided to run this Kickstarter campaign.
  To learn more about Mechaduino:
Latest updates and documentation:
https://hackaday.io/project/11224-mechaduino
http://tropical-labs.com/index.php/mechaduino
Design Files:
https://github.com/jcchurch13
Youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGg_1plkRDMVlN1Q_DBpB8Q
NEMA 23 Adapter:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1653797
Let’s Get Technical:
Processor:
Atmel ATSAMD21G18  -  Arduino Zero compatible
Encoder:
AMS AS5047D - 14-bit magnetic encoder
Motor Driver:
Allegro A4954 - Dual full bridge PWM driver
 
           Mechaduino is Open Source Hardware
  All Mechaduino related materials are released under the
Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike 4.0 License
https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have the first batch of Mechaduinos working here at Tropical Labs! The ones you receive will be nearly identical. We have been working closely with our manufacturer in preparation for this Kickstarter. We have quotes in hand for all the components. We don't anticipate any issues moving forward. We'll keep you in the loop throughout the manufacturing process.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi all,
We've uploaded a significantly improved version of the Mechaduino firmware. It is available here (master branch of our repo). Older versions of the firmware are still available here and here.
Improvements include:

I am pleased to announce that all rewards have shipped with the exception of a few international orders with late or missing phone numbers.
If you are having your reward shipped internationally and have not provided us with your phone number, please do so as soon as possible so that we can send you your reward.

Hi all,
While most backers seem to be getting their Mechaduinos up and running, a few have told us that they received a Mechaduino with a minor manufacturing issue:  a missing bootloader, a missing magnet (PCB), even one with a few missing components!  We contacted our manufacturer earlier this week and asked them to address these problems.

Hi all,
It's taking our manufacturer a little longer than initially anticipated to ship out the last batch of rewards.  I've been told that the rest should be in the mail by the end of the week.  If you have not received your reward, I sincerely apologize for the delay. 
Thank you for your understanding.  I will continue to do everything I can to get them out as soon as possible.

updates.update_userinfo: How to get your Mechaduino up and running
updates.update_content:
For the latest, most up-to-date instructions on how to configure your Mechaduino, please check our hackaday.io page.  In particular, check out the instructions section.  
The latest firmware can be found on our github repository.  
We’ve also created a google group for users to share technical info.
Our manufacturer will begin shipping your rewards tomorrow!

Hi backers!
Great news:  Our manufacturer will begin shipping your Mechaduinos this week!  If you need to change your shipping address, you have 48 hours to do so.
Attention international backers: We have just been informed that we will need a phone number for all rewards shipped outside of the US. Please reply to the message you just received with your phone number.
Hi all!  Our manufacturer has finished soldering up all of the boards! They will begin programming them and assembling the servos next week.  We are on track to ship rewards by the end of the month!

I was not surprised to pay an extra $47 CAD for my $175US (not including $30US shipping) order since it was coming by a courier, DHL. Brokerage was only about $17, the rest was tax to the government. That is hardly piracy. Most courier services are going to charge you the proper tax and a brokerage fee. You're supposed to pay tax when you import something, so for Ontario that is 13% (5% federal, 8% provincial), The brokerage firm used the $180 US declared value (why wasn't it declared $175 by MicroFab?) converted to $235.87 CAD, so that's $30.66 CAD GST/HST tax. There will always be brokerage fees for handling this; $10.50 CAD Processing fee, + $1.37 tax, processing fee of $4.25 CAD + 0.55 tax. Total was $47.33. That's $16.67 CAD in fees above the HST tax on the goods, not really that crazy an amount for a brokerage firm to charge; I've seen brokerage fees as high 100% of the tax and duty on a $400 order. Maybe, you get away without paying GST on goods through the post most of the time, but like it or not, you should be paying the GST on goods you buy. To refuse the order to avoid paying the tax and a fee that is not that much, then make someone resend it, well that would be low. Usually you can use your own broker, but unless you're a company, you probably don't have one of those. These are not unreasonable fees, just part of doing business across the boarder. All in three stepper motors cost me $322.47 CAD, a bit more then I was expecting at the start, but less than $17 for brokerage, about 5% of the total cost.

I'm afraid is DHL, not local customs. It happens to me several times asking for more than $60 for custom clearance of a $20 shipment value. Custom here is 7%, but we need a number to clear by ourself on a customs web for free that DHL does not provide or ask you for extra $30 to give it. After claiming to local authorities, they gave the number for free. It dies not happen with USPS..declaring real value you pay only 7%. Hope it helps next time, avoid international DHL, they are pirates!

I had to pay almost 30$ extra for the shipment. In the end, I had to pay almost 100$ (kickstarter asked for 45$, which was already a lot) for one tiny pcb, and you didn't even include the magnet that it needs...

Why is it you want feedback on your rotary axis? It has no load on it to speak of and its acceleration is much more limited by the friction between the nozzle and the part than stepper. As for accuracy, unless you're placing something crazier than a 256 QFP, you don't really need much more than 1/2 a degree of accuracy.

@Creator: Thanks for clarifying! Instead of a hollow shaft, I can use a different pnp head design, with an offset motor connected to a pulley, like shown on following page - http://petemills.blogspot.co.uk/2014/04/diy-pick-and-place-machine-part-3.html

For picking up and rotating components, I'll possibly be using a hollow shaft motor combined with a vacuum pump. Thanks in advance.
4. Not sure about that, but probably not?

Hi, I noticed that you guys had mentioned in the notes sections on the Step/Dir Diagram that there are a few different ways to supply the 5V Vin power. Is there any reason that a space could not be allocated on the PCB to mount the suggested regulator r-78e5.0-0.5? Is would seem to make sense as it would save a power input wire since a 8-25V input is needed anyways to drive the stepper. Thanks!
I might order more than a single sample... :)

The closed-loop scheme used here is actually better for positioning precision and accuracy, because if you ask for a certain amount of motion, the feedback loop will increase torque until you get that motion. But you have to be realistic about the resolution that an ungeared stepper can achieve -- it has practical limits.

I understand that you are driving the steppers as a BLDC instead of microstepping (1/64 for example), but what kind of resolution can we expect with this kind of setup? For example, if I were to drive a 0.9degree (400steps/rev) NEMA17 at 1/64 microstep, I have a theoretical resolution of 0.014 degrees. What can I expect from this setup?
Great work and I am so happy to see this campaign succeed!

In 3D printers, we see this behavior as ripples in the print spaced 1 full step apart when the printer is moving very slowly. You could probably use the encoder to check for this. If it occurs, a motor with higher resistance and inductance could be selected.
Thanks!
Thanks again for this great project!
Sort of related: do you know offhand what the maximum sample rate is for that encoder? If not, I can look it up, but in case you already have it in mind...

So, I know it's a rev and a fair bit of work, I think in the least, if you don't want epic thermal fail, you need to put the A4954 on the other side of the board, stitching in a bunch of thermal vias that attach the thermal pad of the chip to a copper pour on the near side, and snake the lines you have routed in that area in this revision to a more creative path or placement.
thanks
Any chance you're going to make a version with a beefier driver chip more suited to NEMA 23 (or larger) motors?

campaign.story:
Fireduino with Dual-Core Cortex-M3 processor, integrates high-quality audio Codec and WiFi module, compatible with the Arduino interfaces and Arduino IDE programming perfectly, and supports FireBlock graphics programming. It is not only a perfect programming enlightenment teaching platform, but also an open-source creative prototyping platform.
It is the best upgrade version of Arduino UNO.
Fireduino=Arduino × 2 + Audio module + RTC module + WiFi module + Flash module
It can be programmed using the Arduino IDE, the code style and the mode of operation is fully compatible with the standard of the Arduino. We have provided abundant practical routines, as long as you have learned the Arduino or C language, you can control the Fireduino quickly.
It supports FireBlock which is graphical program software, even if without program experience,you can program easily through assembling the graphic buttons, and flash the program to Fireduino through WiFi transmission. All of these innovative features make ideas realize easily and freely.
It adopts the RKNandD of Rockchip dual core Cortex-M3, with high operating frequency(system core up to 250MHz,calculation core up to 500MHz), and integrates the SPI Flash which with 8M byte high-capacity, it has further extended the space of creation.
Fireduino integrates 1MByte SRAM, hardware decoder and Codec, all this just in order to play the high-quality audio of 24bit/192KHz perfectly.
It supports DLNA wireless audio sharing technology, phone audio can be pushed to Fireduino via WiFi, and Fireduino will release the wonderful music to every corner of the room rapidly. So you can enjoy music and relax yourself.
It with LCD controller, supports TFT LCD which the resolution up to 400x400, and with simple drawing routines of Arduino IDE, so that you can better express the creative scene.
Addition to LCD interface, Fireduino also has the interfaces which are fully compatible with Arduino, such as I2C, SPI, ADC, GPIO, PWM, UART.
Make with Fireduino
Fireduino can be used to develop a lot of things,such as WiFI player, Robot, Smart Home and so on. It is an excellent board for maker, you can easily use it to develop your own products and create more possibilities.
We have a wealth of resources to help you use Fireduino, there are Community, Wiki, Download, Github and so on. You can discuss problems, view data, as well as download files. So that you can use Fireduino to develop your things easily and conveniently.
 Please help us reach this goal by sharing our ideas with your friends
  Rewards
 We look forward to your support and you will get the following rewards:

Fireduino Timeline
 Meet  the team
We are Firefly. We are good at hardware and software development, application development and cloud services support, focus on open-source hardware design, as well as disseminating open source culture and knowledge, have accumulated years of experience in design and development. We believe we can complete Fireduino to provide an open-source creative prototyping platform for you successfully.You can get more information about us on our official website: http://www.t-firefly.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We expect to receive the certificates of CE, FCC and ROHS before July 2016 and finish the mass production and ship to backers within the promised time. We not only have experienced hardware and software technical personnel, but also cooperate with reliable international logistics companies to ensure Fireduino will be sent to backers. Please note that you may need to pay the duties according to local policy. If there are problems during the shipping, we will follow up and handle on time to make sure you will receive the package. We believe we can overcome challenges and handle unexpected events.

If you have any questions about Fireduino, you can contact us via email service@t-firefly.com. Thanks for your support!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Fireduino supports LINE IN function, it can play audio from other device while connecting other device's audio output to Fireduino's LINE IN interfaces. Fireduino has two Channels of LINE IN which can be switched easily.

Via adding support for DLNA on the audio library, users can push phone audio stream to make it  play on Fireduino through network. In this way,  Fireduino is able to  become a network music player as expected (wiith this additional function)

campaign.story:
What is WiThumb?
WiThumb is an Arduino compatible USB powered WiFi IoT development board with 6 DOF IMU, precision temperature sensor and optional plastic case.
With WiThumb, adding WiFi, temperature sensor, Gyroscope and Accelerometer to your IoT project is a breeze. In addition, optional plastic case not only protects the circuits but also adds professional look to it. Why bother messy wiring or ugly project boxes while you can get this elegantly dressed up WiThumb.
In addition, WiThumb could be powered by standard USB type-A ports found in many power adapters, computers, TV, routers, cars, solar chargers and etc. It makes WiThumb an ideal device to deploy your applications anywhere.
Languages and Applications
WiThumb is not only compatible with Arduino, it also runs micropython (a lean and efficient implementation of the Python3 programming language) and LUA.
In addition, being Arduino compatible, many sensor and WiFi libraries are readily available. For example, it is very easy to build a WiFi thermometer, to post the data to IoT cloud (e.g. on data.sparkfun.com) and to plot graphs using Analog.io).
Also, it takes no time to build a local IoT cloud with Raspberry Pi and WiThumb because of the MQTT protocol.
(Disclaimer. Mentioning of these companies doesn't imply their direct involvements nor endorsement. This is for reference only) 
Benefits
Compact (1.9 inch x 0.85 inch PCB)
USB Powered. Plug in anywhere. 
Large community (Arduino, ESP8266 WiFi)
Easy to program  
Easy to carry
Low cost
Low power (deep sleep mode)
Plastic case protects the electronics
Expandable 
Specifications
32-bit MCU with 802.11b/g/n WiFi (ESP8266)
Integrated TCP/IP protocol stack
4MB Flash memory
Precision temperature sensor (+/- 0.25C typical accuracy)
6-axis Gyroscope + Accelerometer
IO pins: One 10-bit ADC, I2C and SPI (GPIO pins G12-15)
Breadboard friendly (0.1" pitch header holes)
Optional plastic case
Front and Back of WiThumb
  Connects to USB Type-A adapters
Comparisons
Applications  
 Possibilities are endless. To name a few:
Internet connected thermometer
IMU (Inertial measurement unit) for drones and robots
As a smart device in home automation
WiFi Access Point
Home/Office Security (using IMU)
Industrial temperature sensing (e.g. in data center, storage)
IoT gateway
WiFi sniffer
Monitor TV usage (e.g. WiThumb is powered when TV is on)
Monitor driver's driving habits
With additional circuits through I2C, GPIOs and ADC, WiThumb could be the controller of many projects (WiFi controlled switches, LED control, WiFi compass, WiFi enabled soil moisture sensor, etc.)
Store sensor data to the cloud
  Example:Monitor TV usage. WiThumb gets powered when TV is on.
  Example: WiThumb as in-vehicle IMU
Programming
WiThumb is compatible with Arduino and could be programmed through USB from Arduino (TM) IDE. There is a large community and many sample code and libraries available online.
Program with Arduino IDE
Schedule
In our last KickStarter project, we shipped the pledges (robots) one month ahead of schedule. Unless there is any unexpected event, we have high confidence in the following schedule.
Tentative schedule
Related topics: WiFi, USB, IoT, ESP8266, Sparkfun, Adafruit, DIY, Makers,thermometer, Arduino, Raspberry Pi, IMU, Drone, Physics, PCB, coding, AI Thinker, Espressif, Oaks, NodeMCU, Robots, MQTT, Oshpark
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
WiThumb has evolved from initial concept to the existing prototype. The design is believed to be final. However, we'd like to go through pre-production stage to test more parts.

The primary risk of this project is potential delay due to manufacturing and shipping partners or issues found during pre-production testing.

The components used in WiThumb are readily available in the market. If the demand of WiThumb exceeds the supply, it may cause delay to the schedule. However, this risk deems to be very low.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Pre-production Units
I received the pre-production units today and started testing them. So far, everything looks good. I am hoping to ship the rewards for "Developer's deal (super early)" pledges some time next week after more testings. Most likely, we are 2-3 weeks ahead of schedule.

updates.update_userinfo: You could get a Free WiThumb
updates.update_content:
Our Kickstarter campaign ended successfully. Thank everyone who supported the project. This is just the beginning of the next phase. We are working hard to ensure that you will get your reward as soon as possible.
In my last update, I mentioned that pre-production design was submitted. The PCB company already fabricated the boards and is going to assemble pre-production units.
Since the funding goal has been met, I decided to submit the pre-production design for fabrication before the campaign ends. If it goes smoothly, you will receive your reward sooner.

Based on some feedback from our supporters, there are a couple of improvements made to WiThumb
1. The USB-UART bridge on WiThumb is now going to be CP2104 from Silicon Labs as opposed to the CH340G. This is because CP2104 has better driver support for Macs.
2. The temperature sensor was originally directly underneath ESP8266 WiFi chip. Due to the aforementioned change, it is now possible to move the temperature sensor to the top side of the PCB.

updates.update_userinfo: Improved USB chip and component placement

campaign.story:
Why have I decided to create this shield?
Oscilloscope and waveform generator are most needed equipment on every makers bench, and are some of the most expensive ones.
Most of us already have many development boards. Most popular are Arduino and manufactured ST Microelectronics Nucleo and Discovery. As both have an Arduino format connector I have decided to create an Arduino format oscilloscope and an arbitrary waveform generator shield.
Prototype of the oscilloscope shield
  PLAY

 Parameters
The technical details can vary from board to board as they are fitted with different processors. Below are for STM Nucleo 446RE board.
Oscilloscope:
Up to three channels real 5 or 3MSPS (fast mode) or 2.4MSPS per channel*
Single channel real 9MSPS (super fast mode) or 7.2MSPS in fast mode (on some boards 10MSPS)
Triggers: level, rising or falling edge. Any channel can be selected as a trigger source.
External trigger source
Bandwidth: 50MHz+.250MHz front end amplifiers.
Resolution: 12 and 8 bits (software selectable)
Sample memory: up to 96k samples
RMS and duty cycle calculations for entire captured wave or limited by cursors
Horizontal (voltage) and vertical (time) cursors
Selectable number of samples and number of frames captures
Vertical resolution 5mV / div to 1V / div
Horizontal resolution from 0.22us / div to 1h / div (actually probably up to 10h /div  but I did not have enough patience to have tested it)
Any horizontal & vertical resolution  (for example 21.5us / div & 45.5mV / div)
Communication with computer via virtual COM port (speed up to 921600), or full speed USB port - board depending
GND / AC / DC coupling (pro board)
Arbitrary Waveform Generator
Up to 4MSPS per channel
Two channels
Nine predefined waveforms
Any mathematical formula can be used to generate signal [for example sin(x)*(exp(cos(x)) ] - see the videos below
WAV files player
Saved oscillograms player
Two separate functions which can be combined. Waveforms can be added, subtracted and multiplied. Second waveform can be modulated by the first one. Amplitude, frequency and PWM modulation available.
Any top and bottom voltage
12 bit resolution
Up to 4096 samples per frame
API to add custom functions
Logic Analyser (will be available as a free upgrade end of September)
8 channels
I2C decoder
USART (RS232) decore
SPI decoder
CAN decoder
API for adding custom functions
Videos
Simple signals
PLAY

500kHz, 800kHz & 1.4MHz square signal in Fast Mode
PLAY

Custom functions
PLAY

Combining functions
PLAY

 Fast and normal mode
PLAY

 *see the comparison table - some boards with entry level procesors may have limited ADC throuput to 1MSPS or 75KSPS (Arduino Uno)
Nucleo boards
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The design is almost ready. Software was tested and it needs only some minor tweaking. I can supply software now - it can be used without the shield. 
Shields will be available end of August at the latest, but there is always a small risk that the suppliers will delay or supply poor quality products. But I do not use any far east PCB manufacturers, all my boards are made in Europe. I do not have to wait weeks for my deliveries, and European manufacturers are usually much more reliable and offer much better quality.

campaign.story:
Ich leite seit 2010 Technik Kurse für Kinder ab 12 Jahren.
Es gibt viele gute Roboter Bausätze.
Jedoch verstehen meine Teilnehmer nur wenig Englisch.
Zudem, sollte ein Bausatz optimalerweise kostengünstig sein, damit ihn die Teilnehmer nach Hause nehmen können um ihn weiter zu entwickeln.
Dafür hatte ich vor einem Jahr einen eigenen Bausazu zusammengestellt: VIVIBOT den Arduino Roboter. Er besteht aus folgenden Komponenten:
UNO (Arduino UNO China Klon)
Vivishield (Eigener einfacher Motorshield)
2 Getriebemotoren mit Rädern
Ultraschallsensor
Servo
Kabel für Baterie, Servo, Sensor und für Motoren
Schrauben, Distanzscheiben und Muttern
LED's, Lautsprecher und Schalter
3mm Sperrholzplatte
Die Grundplatte kann selber gestaltet werden, jeder Roboter sieht anderst aus.
Vivibot kann Fahren, Hindernissen ausweichen, blinken und Melodien Pipsen.
Ich möchte nun eine neue Version des Bausatzes herstellen, ich werde die Platine optimieren, den Bausatz und das Beispielprogramm vereinfachen.
Zudem, damit Vivibot auch für fortgeschrittene Arduinobenutzer und Opensourcebenutzer interessant ist, werde ich weitere Beispielcodes, 3D-Druck-Dateien und Stücklisten auf der Vivibot-Homepage veröffentlichen.
Baue deinen eigenen Arduino Roboter! Open Source, als Bausatz, mit deutscher Anleitung. Lerne zu Basteln, zu Löten und zu Programmieren.
Oder organisiere selber einen Kurs, für deinen Hackerspace oder deine Schule.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Dies ist mein erstes Croudfounding Projekt. 
Ich versende die Belonungen nur innerhalb der Schweiz.
in dem Letzten Jahr sind bei mir in Workshops fast 100 Vivibots entstanden. Ich kann mir also vorstellen, weitere Unterstützer zu finden.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Introducing the Hatch Notebook
Hatch Notebook is a tool that makes it easier to take your ideas from concept to reality, or “Hatch” them. It's a simple, 3-step system to generate and evaluate ideas, keep them organized, and then design and plan them.
The Hatch notebook will help you find an idea that you’re passionate about and then take action on it.
Hatching ideas requires a blend of creativity and practicality, inspiration and perseverance. Hatch is a place for both—it has enough structure to guide you, but also the flexibility to allow for all different types of people to use it for their creative endeavors.
Organize all your ideas in one place  
If you're like us, your ideas end up in all different places—blank notebooks, dry erase board, napkins—you know how it goes. Without an organized system, it's hard to know which ideas are good, or how excited you are about a particular idea. 
With the Hatch notebook, you’ll be able to see all your ideas at a glance and decide which ones you’re excited about.
We’ve found that having one place for all our ideas helps generate more ideas, and make connections between them.
Hatch will also help you stay motivated and committed throughout the process of bringing an idea to life.
Bringing an idea to life can be an emotional roller coaster. The Hatch notebook will keep you committed and inspired throughout the process!
How does it work?
There are 3 steps in the Hatch process.
STEP 1: Conceive
First, you list your ideas by category to create an unorthodox table of contents as you enter page numbers. As you fill in the excitement & difficulty levels of each idea, you’ll be able to see which ones might be worth pursuing at a glance.
Conceive - TOC page
There are also blank dot grid pages that you can use to brainstorm and mindmap to generate new ideas. And, we’ve included some tips & suggestions for how to get the ideas flowing in the back of the notebook (just in case you get stuck!)
Conceive - Brainstorm page
STEP 2: Incubate
Next, evaluate and define your ideas by answering some questions. This will help you figure out which ones you’re most passionate about (and most viable) and want to Hatch. 
Incubate spread
STEP 3: Hatch
Here, you'll fill out your project specs and an action plan that will keep you moving forward. Then you can use the blank pages to sketch, take notes, code, write, or anything else that's part of your process. Dream big, be creative, and have fun!
Hatch specs and action plan
    How many pages in each section?
Conceive section 
4 pages to list and categorize your ideas 
16 blank dot grid pages to brainstorm ideas
Incubate section
14 spreads with questions to help you evaluate your ideas to decide which ones to pursue
Hatch section
5 project sub-sections to design, develop and plan your ideas; 18 pages each, with 1 page for specifications and action plan and the others blank for your sketches and notes
Guidelines, tips & resources
10 pages of guidelines, tips & resources at the back, to guide you if you need it, while being unobtrusive if you don't
Plus, there are quotes at the beginning of each section to inspire and motivate you when you start to have doubts, to encourage you to trust yourself and keep going, and to remind you that you're not alone.

We're still finishing the content for the Guidelines, tips & resources section, and are open to suggestions for what you'd like to see!
Features  
We've spent a lot of time on the design details and selection of materials to make a notebook that looks great, is fun to use, and you'll love to carry with you everywhere.
      Color Options
Available in Slate Grey or Midnight Blue
Because we reached our $30k Stretch Goal, we've added a midnight blue cover color option! Backers will get to choose from the 2 colors via the survey at the end of the campaign. You'll be able to split your pledge between the two color options if you'd like.
    This is one of our prototypes. The final book will have a sewn binding so that it always lays flat!
  Why a paper notebook?
Just the act of writing down an idea on paper makes it more real and gives it value in a way that digital format does not. There's so much digital media these days that it it feels fleeting, less permanent. When we make a note on our phones we often completely forget it's there. 
We find that when you write all your ideas down in one place where you can see them all together, you start to have more ideas and draw connections between them. The key to having great ideas is having a lot of ideas, so all ideas—even the bad ones—serve a purpose. This is harder to do in digital format because it's not as easy to flip through and see things. Also for us, it's more fun to sketch and draw on paper. And you can look back at your notebook for years to see what your thinking was at that time.
Why Kickstarter?
Our goal of $15,000 will fund an initial run of notebooks, and the money will be used solely to produce and deliver Hatch Notebooks. We’re excited to launch another product on Kickstarter. There’s a sense of community around bringing a project to life that’s unique to this platform.
We hope you like Hatch, and we’d love to hear your thoughts! The layout isn't set in stone, and we may make changes based on your feedback.
Previous campaigns:
Foodie Dice
Mixology Dice
For more about us, see Our Bio
Share to get the PDF for FREE  
We believe that ideas can come from anywhere, that no idea is too big or too small, and that ideas can change the world. We’re very excited about what we’ve created and even more excited about helping people develop their ideas and find something that’s meaningful to them. We want to create a community around launching ideas, and we want everyone to be a part of it, whether they’re able to donate to the project or not.
That’s why we’ve decided to share the digital version for free.
All you have to do is:
1: Share our project on any social media platform with the #hatchnotebook hashtag
2: Send us a note at hatchdigital@twotumbleweeds.co with a screenshot or a link of where you shared it, and we’ll send you a PDF at the end of the Kickstarter campaign.
Use one or both of the links below to get a pre-populated tweet or Facebook post shared directly from your account. 
Share on Instagram  /  Share on Facebook  /  Share on Twitter
Our Inspiration & Process
We came up with this idea about a year ago, and started using a basic version to organize our own ideas. We quickly found that having one place for all our ideas helped us generate more ideas and make connections that we wouldn’t have otherwise. Also, we found that just the act of writing down an idea made it more real and helped us stay committed.
Over the past year, we've created and used several prototypes, sought feedback from different types of makers, and continually refined and revised the concept. We’ve learned so much about book binding and printing. It's come quite a long way from the initial spark, and we've enjoyed the process.
How did we get from Foodie Dice to Hatch? On the surface, these two products might seem unrelated, but at their core they both inspire creativity and a sense of adventure, and that's our ultimate goal.  
Connect with us and share what you create!
Instagram  //  Facebook
Thank you so much for your support! We can't wait to see what you'll "Hatch"!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest challenge with any physical product is manufacturing. We spent a lot of time learning about printing and binding, and sought quotes from several printers. From those, we selected one that we’re excited to partner with. They’re in the United States, have been in business for over 100 years, and they do beautiful work.

We also learned a lot with our previous campaigns, Foodie Dice and Mixology Dice (which we delivered on time), and we have the infrastructure already in place to easily ship rewards.

If our campaign is funded, we‘ll dedicate ourselves to delivering a quality product, and we’ll be transparent if challenges do arise. We want the Hatch Notebook in your hands, helping you bring your ideas to life.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: We just launched a Kickstarter Gold campaign — Early Birds are going fast!

updates.update_content:
Hello,
We're on track according to our last update (our printer is supposed to ship to us 10/7), which should have us shipping the week of 10/17.
Surveys—we're going to lock them tomorrow night, so we can process your rewards into our shipping software. If you haven't filled out your survey or need to make any changes, please do so!

Hello Kickstarters,
We haven't posted an update in awhile, so we just wanted to send you a quick message to let you know that Hatch is in production and everything is on track for September delivery. If you haven't completed your survey yet, please do so! For those new to Kickstarter, the survey is how we get your shipping address and color choice. You can change your address in Kickstarter up until we're ready to ship.

Hello backers! 
Many people have been asking when they'll receive the PDF version of the Hatch notebook, so we wanted to send a quick update to let you know that we're putting the finishing touches on it, and plan to send out a link by July 15th (hopefully sooner). We'll also send surveys (so you can choose your color and provide your address) around the same time.

Hello Backers!
We're in the final hours of our campaign, and wanted to send a quick reminder that this is your last chance to adjust your pledge. 
We've said it before, but it can't be said enough — thank you!! It's such an incredible feeling to be wrapping up our third successful Kickstarter campaign. Each one is different, but all of them have left us with a huge feeling of accomplishment, and that's the feeling that we wish for all of you. Whatever your idea is, whatever creative endeavor you pursue, there's big satisfaction in putting it out into the world (even if it's scary sometimes!), and we know that Hatch can help you do that. We can't wait to see what you create.

How many times did you forget to turn off the fan after morning shower? 
EcoFan is a smart Bathroom/Washroom Fan powered by small computer chip and PC Fan
Cheaper and better, use computer fan that ship billions, large volume means low price, better quality.  
Quieter, again, use computer fan that is so advanced. Well tested and able to run 10,000 hours.
Smarter, built-in microprocessor enable fine control. Arduino source code provided so you can add your own features!
Built-in 433mHz RF remote module
PWM, means you can change Fan speed
It is powered by Arduino firmware and wireless remote control module. Wireless module use 315/433 mHz. If you have WiFi to 315/433 gateway, you can use it to control EcoFan. IFTTT is also possible.
EcoFan, a smart bathroom and washroom fan that’s powered by a small computer chip and a PC-grade fan. To put it simply, this fan is far and away better than anything else that is being used in bathroom and washroom projects on a regular basis. EcoFan will immediately set your bathroom or washroom apart and make all of your hygiene activities a pleasure rather than an eardrum-aching chore.
EcoFan is based on a computer fan that has shipped billions of pieces, meaning that the price is already competitively low and that the quality has already been established. The fan runs for 10,000 hours, and it has been tested and reviewed over a period of many years. Enabling fine control, the powerful microprocessor comes built in, and we are providing the Arduino source code to anyone who would like to add their own features as well. A 433mHz RF remote module also comes built-in, and you can change the fan speed exactly to your liking, not just with the one or two settings that come with only the most advanced models currently on the market.
Fan controller comes with firmware written in Arduino, default mode is a timer that will shutoff the fan after 30 minutes. 
You can use remote to configure the timer, change how long the fan will run after you turn on the power. 
Also, you can turn on/off using remote, use remote to let fan run continuous.
Source code will be provided, if you know coding, you can change it to whatever you want.
Prototype:
Fan with controller prototype
 Controller prototype with enclosure
 Controller prototype
Early prototype:
Arduino Source Code:
Will published to github after this project.
The Story:
I got the idea when my washroom fan was broken and need to be replaced. I opened the cover, took off the fan, took a picture and about to go to HomeDepot to get a similar model.  
What I discovered shocked me: the fan I was looking for was rated 50 cubic feet per minute, similar to my computer fan, but it was using ten times the power that my computer fan was. On top of that, my computer fan is brush-less, minimizing the amount of noise it emits.
So I did some research and put the 12V power supply and PC-Fan together to see if it works.
My old fan:
 12V AC-DC power supply and PC-Fan
It worked really well! Exceeding my expectation!
After several months. I am thinking, why not add a timer to it? Because I am always forgetting to turn off my bathroom fan after I take my morning shower. That’s how the Arudino firmware came into play. After multiple prototypes, I got EcoFan to a place where I was happy with it, and I have since been using it in all four bathrooms in my home.
Rewards:
There are many Plug & socket types around the world: http://www.worldstandards.eu/electricity/plugs-and-sockets/
We have USB power supply for Type A and Type C plug. 
For backers from USA, Canada, Mexico & Japan, we will ship the USB power supply with Type A.  
For backers from Europe, South America & Asia(outside of Japan), we will ship power supply with Type C.
Please make sure your can use either Type A or Type C plug.

campaign.story:
Introduction  
"Backers... Thank you for backing our previous campaign..." From our previous successfully fulfilled Kickstarter experience and feedback we wanted to create this advanced board which could be fun for tinkerers, hobbyists and geeks (like us!) to control appliances remotely using just your android phone or to connect sensors which will magically turn on/off lights and appliances making them 'smart'.
We present to you the "WiFi Quad Relay Board". An advanced version of our previous ESP8266 based WiFi enabled board with which also includes a 100-230V /5V AC/DC power supply so that you will be able to connect it directly to AC mains - creating 4 WiFi enabled smart devices at the same time. It also has the node MCU compatible header where you can connect I2C based devices like an OLED or sensors like PIR, IR, Temperature etc.... so you can not only control four individual appliances but also add sensors and displays to make your home as 'smart' as you want.
We have also thrown in an onboard USB to UART converter which can connect to the ESP8266 module and can be used to program the ESP8266 to your liking.
We are looking for your support to improve the hardware and manufacture it.
Please support us by backing our project to make our simple and fun project successful.
Features & Specifications
Board consists of 100-240V AC to 5V DC converter. 
Four Relays to connect four AC/DC loads. Both NC/NO connectors of the relay are provided.
Can connect additional sensors like PIR, IR, Temperature, Humidity, Limit switch etc.
WiFi Quad Relay Board can be programmed as "MQTT Client" for Networking/Home automation integration.
SSID and Password can be set directly from the mobile phone web browser using default firmware.
LED for Testing which is connected to a GPIO and also as indicator when the relay go on /off.
Dimensions of the board are 145 X 60 X 22 mm.
Block Diagram 
WiFi Quad Relay Board
WiFi Quad Relay Board
  WiFi Quad Relay Board
  WiFi Quad Relay Board
  WiFi Quad Relay Board
  WiFi Quad Relay Board with PIR Sensor
WiFi Quad Relay Board with Android APP
WiFi Quad Relay Board with Android APP
  WiFi Quad Relay Board with Android APP
WiFi Smart Strip
Making of WiFi Smart Strip by using WiFi Quad Relay Board and a plastic box (Dimensions 220*155 *60 mm)
Plastic box consists of 4 sockets, 4 Two way switches and a WiFi Quad Relay Board


WiFi Quad Relay Board with casing
  WiFi Quad Relay Board with Plastic Box
  What can we make with a WiFi Quad Relay Board
"WiFi Smart Strip" creating WiFi smart strip using the WiFi Quad Relay Board with 4 sockets & 4 two-way switches.
"Anti-Theft System" when motion is detected activate siren and close your door.
"Industrial Applications" where sequence of operations is perform based on  sensors data.
"Home Automation" to activate different appliances at same time or serially. (once you are awake switch on your heater, a washing machine, a Coffee machine).
"IoT PIR Sensor Board" (When motion detected it can activate buzzer and inform the user).
"A Temperature Logger" (Based on the temperature settings can activate the devices and inform the user).
"Tank Water Controller" (Based on the water level it can switch on motor and log the motor timings).
Using multiple Sensors like PIR, Temperature etc control different appliances parallely or serially. 
These are the some of the applications of WiFi Quad Relay Board.
Instructable for one of the example for creating a Smart Strip using WiFi Quad Relay Board
http://www.instructables.com/id/NodeMCU-ESP8266-Based-Switch-Board-with-Raw-TCPIP-/
Initial Version of WiFi Quad Relay Board with Onion Omega and MQTT for Home Automation & IOT

WiFi Smart Switch with single relay 
WiFi Smart Switch
Features WiFi Smart Switch Single Relay
Attiny 85 Microntroller 
The board can also connect other standard Bluetooth/Rf modules as the communication is UART based
WIFI Smart Switch can be programmed as MQTT Client
Can connect additional sensors like PIR, IR, Temperature, Humidity, Limit switch etc.
Has 5V/9V input and the Attiny85 can run at 5V or 3.3V depending on jumper position this will help while interfacing 5V sensors.
A Relay to control AC/DC Loads. 
REWARDS  
IF you want to back us with two different rewards than please add this extra amount to your current reward.

$15 Bare PCB + $3 shipping cost = $18  
$29 WiFi Quad Realy board + $3 shipping cost = $32

For any other rewards please contact us.

BARE PCB REWARD
In these rewards only the Bare PCB is provided without the components. and most of the components are smd type (Resistor & Capacitor are 0805 package). Along with this you will also get the BOM for your reference.

For ANY REWARD ADD EXTRA 
$14 for 1* Plastic casing + 4 sockets + 4 Two way switches for WiFi Quad Relay Board.  (Note: Power cord not included) 
We will be providing the wiring instructions. (Have fun with wiring).

$15 for 1 * WiFi Smart Switch with Single Relay. 

Just message us after backing. 


Shipping
For shipping we will be using standard International and Domestic postal service.
The People
We are a small group of professionals who like to develop easy simple boards to execute hobby projects. The group consists of both well experienced as well has young and dynamic people capable of handling projects from design to production. We have in our team multidisciplinary design engineers as well as professional production and quality control people. We assure you that we will see to that each of our project backer will be satisfied with our systematic approach and by our scheduled project product delivery. We also take up Hardware, PCB Design, PCBA Assembling, Testing & Software development work. If you have any such project which you wish to outsource you can contact us.
Where will the funds be used
Manufacturing of the Hardware.
Improved version of the present board.

Risks and challenges
Every project starts with understanding the risk involved in it . Some are anticipated risk and some surprise us. Having team members who have taken up projects individually and have executed them from design to production, we don’t think we will have any issue in solving the various problem that will be coming on our way. Furthermore, having some team members who specialize in production and quality control, we think we're well prepared and will execute the project without many hurdles and delay.Also we have successfully completed our first kickstarter campaign so we are now better aware of the risks and challenges. 

Anticipated Risk.

· Feedback implementation in design delay

· Material delivery delays

· Quality Control and Testing Delay

· Shipment delivery Delay

Having mentioned a few we also do consider some risk which do get noticed when we are actually executing it but we assure you that we will put all our effort to solve it and deliver the reward to our backers
